Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story: Tonight, as I drove my last passenger—a young woman heading to a casual dinner—I felt the familiar tug of responsibility. She chatted about her day, unconcerned with time, and I made sure to drive safely, obeying every traffic rule, as expected of a good taxi driver. My job was to get her there comfortably and on time, even if she wasn’t in a rush. But my mind kept drifting to my own plans: a late-evening music session with friends at my apartment. We’d been looking forward to it all week, but I knew the building’s quiet hours started soon, and my neighbor, who always left his windows open, had complained before. As a citizen, I was expected to respect the rules and my neighbors’ peace. The weight of both roles pressed on me—one demanding I be reliable and attentive to my passenger, the other urging me to be considerate and law-abiding at home. I could feel the tension building inside, torn between the urge to unwind with friends and the duty to maintain harmony in my community.
